channel.title: Visualization on Ronald's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Visualization on Ronald's Blog

item.title: Time Series
item.description: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Time series are somewhat similiar to scatter plots in the sense that you can have points on the graph, but the major point that you are looking at with these are trends over time. A way to equate this to something familiar would be looking at a graph for the trends of a particular stock, whether the value went up or down over time with a line showing that trend.

item.title: Data Visualization-Scatter Plots
item.description: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) There will be times when working in Data Science where you will want to visualize the output of your data. In the 9:00am session of MIS 150, we worked on making scatter plots in RStudio, running a query searching for players with at least 400 career homeruns. #Extractcing Data---------------------------- query<-"SELECT playerID,sum(HR) AS career_HR ,sum(SO) AS career_SO FROM Batting GROUP BY playerID HAVING sum(HR)>=400" result<-sqldf(query) #Visulaizing Data---------------------------- ggplot()+ geom_point(data=result,aes(x=career_SO,y=career_HR), size=3, color="blue")+ ggtitle("Career Strikeouts vs.
